title.value: Home alone: A population neuroscience investigation of brain morphology substrates
title.justification: The title is directly mentioned in the paper header.
title.quote: Home alone: A population neuroscience investigation of brain morphology substrates

extractions.description: This paper explores the morphological brain differences associated with living alone, using a large sample from the UK Biobank. The study investigates how solitary living affects brain structures, particularly focusing on the default mode network, and assesses sex-specific neural differences. It correlates brain morphology with behavioral traits like loneliness and social support.

type.justification: The study involves data collection and analysis of brain morphology from a large cohort to draw conclusions about the impact of solitary living, thus making it an empirical study.
type.quote: we systematically explore the morphological manifestations associated with singular living in ∼40,000 UK Biobank participants.

name.justification: The research involves studying brain structures and their relation to behavior, which falls under neuroscience.
name.quote: A population neuroscience investigation of brain morphology substrates

name.justification: The study utilizes a large population from the UK Biobank to draw conclusions.
name.quote: A population neuroscience investigation of brain morphology substrates

name.justification: The paper examines the neural basis of social behaviors such as living alone.
name.quote: The neurobiological commonalities between the emotional states of loneliness and living alone.

name.justification: The dataset used in the study is explicitly mentioned as the UK Biobank.
name.quote: This population neuroscience study set out to systematically trace out brain manifestations linked to living alone in the ∼40,000 UK Biobank cohort.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference to the dataset aligns with the standard acknowledgement of the UK Biobank data resource.
referenced_paper_title.quote: All researchers in good standing can ask for access to the UK Biobank at https://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/.

name.justification: The library PyMC3 is mentioned as being used for the Bayesian data analysis in the study.
name.quote: The approximation of the posterior distributions was carried out by the NUTS sampler (Gelman et al., 2014), a type of Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC), using the PyMC3 software (Salvatier et al., 2016).

referenced_paper_title.value: Probabilistic programming in Python using PyMC3
referenced_paper_title.justification: The library use is referenced alongside research for Bayesian analysis, consistent with PyMC3's documentation and publications.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Probabilistic programming in Python using PyMC3. PeerJ Comput. Sci. 2
